bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 26, 1923

div1.p: Truby relates Binnie's condition. He enjoyed his trip to Europe with the Keans in 1921. He discusses upcoming assignments to Panama or the Philippines.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 26, 1923
div1.opener:
AET/MP
United States Army
Letterman General Hospital
Presidio of San Francisco,
San Francisco, Cal.
September 26, 1923.
Colonel J. R. Kean,
Hdqrs. 1st Corps Area,
Army Base,
Boston 9, Massachusetts.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I was very glad to get your letter of
September 19th with reference to Colonel Binnie. He had a
cerebral hemorrhage in July, 1921. I imagine that he is not
well fixed financially and so became a Veterans' Bureau case.
He was at the Army and Navy Hospital at Hot Springs for six
months and then, on account of the hot weather, was transferred
to the Letterman in July, 1922. He has been a patient here
since that time with the exception of about three months last
winter when he was transferred to the Navy Hospital at San
Diego, California. His disability at present consists of the
loss of use of his right arm, complete amnesia for reading, and
almost complete amnesia for speech. His general physical con-
dition is excellent. He walks well and is up and about all the
time. On account of his difficulty in speaking he is, I think,
quite sensitive about seeing his old friends. He can say
“Yes” and “No” but is rarely able to say more than two or three
words without considerable confusion.

Mrs. Binnie is in San Francisco and takes
him out for a ride in their automobile every day.

We have given Colonel Binnie one of our best
rooms in the officers' ward and have done everything possible to
make him happy and contented. He likes the Letterman Hospital
better than any place he has found up to this time.

Mrs. Truby and I called on Colonel and Mrs.
Canby who are now stationed here. They told us that you and Mrs.
Kean were contemplating another trip to Europe. I wish that we
could all go with you again. Our trip to Europe together in 1921
represents one of our happiest experiences. My girls are always

referring to it and I am sure we would like to repeat it. However,
as I will be due for foreign service within a few months, our path
will probably be across the Pacific instead of the Atlantic. I
would greatly prefer service in Panama to the Philippines as it
would simplify the schooling problem for the girls, for there is
nothing in the Philippines in the way of high schools which they
could attend. Elizabeth will be ready for Vassar next year and
Barbara is in the second year of high school. I mentioned this to
General Ireland when he was here but up to this time he has not in-
formed me whether I am to go to Panama or to the Philippines. If
you decide to go to Europe and then continue your travels around the
globe you will probably find us either in Manila or in Panama and
we would be delighted to have you stay with us.

Mrs. Truby and the girls join me in very best wishes
for you and Mrs. Kean.
